paragraphs.text: %md ## Explicit Semantic Analysis (ESA) for Text Analytics Explicit Semantic Analysis (ESA) is an unsupervised algorithm for feature extraction of explicit features based on an existing knowledge base. It is the process of understanding the meaning of a section of text as a combination of the concepts found in the text. Compared to other techniques such as Latent Dirichlet Association (LDA) or Term Frequency-Inverse Document Frequency (TF-IDF), ESA offers some unique benefits. Most notably, it improves text document categorization by calculating `semantic relatedness` (how similar in meaning two words or pieces of text are to each other) between the documents and a set of topics that are explicitly defined and described by humans. The Oracle Machine Learning for R function *ore.odmESA* extracts text-based features from a corpus of documents and performs document similarity comparisons. All processing occurs inside Oracle Autonomous Database. In this notebook, we'll use the Wikipedia Model as an example: - Create an OML4R proxy ESA model object for the pre-loaded Wikipedia model - Examples of using the Wiki ESA model - Basic ESA Wiki model features for words - Basic ESA Wiki model features for phrases - ESA Wiki Model document similarity on phrases - ESA Wiki Model document similarity on long phrases *Note: The pre-built Wikipedia model must be installed in your Autonomous Database instance to run this notebook. See instructions below.* Copyright (c) 2022 Oracle Corporation ###### The Universal Permissive License (UPL), Version 1.0 ---

msg.data:
Explicit Semantic Analysis (ESA) for Text Analytics

Explicit Semantic Analysis (ESA) is an unsupervised algorithm for feature extraction of explicit features based on an existing knowledge base. It is the process of understanding the meaning of a section of text as a combination of the concepts found in the text. Compared to other techniques such as Latent Dirichlet Association (LDA) or Term Frequency-Inverse Document Frequency (TF-IDF), ESA offers some unique benefits. Most notably, it improves text document categorization by calculating semantic relatedness (how similar in meaning two words or pieces of text are to each other) between the documents and a set of topics that are explicitly defined and described by humans.

The Oracle Machine Learning for R function ore.odmESA extracts text-based features from a corpus of documents and performs document similarity comparisons. All processing occurs inside Oracle Autonomous Database.

In this notebook, we'll use the Wikipedia Model as an example:

  • Create an OML4R proxy ESA model object for the pre-loaded Wikipedia model
  • Examples of using the Wiki ESA model
  • Basic ESA Wiki model features for words
  • Basic ESA Wiki model features for phrases
  • ESA Wiki Model document similarity on phrases
  • ESA Wiki Model document similarity on long phrases

Note: The pre-built Wikipedia model must be installed in your Autonomous Database instance to run this notebook. See instructions below.

Copyright (c) 2022 Oracle Corporation

The Universal Permissive License (UPL), Version 1.0

paragraphs.text:
%md
## Using the Wikipedia model as an example

msg.data: Using the Wikipedia model as an example

paragraphs.title: Delete existing policies and create new policies for the Wiki Lexer
paragraphs.text:
%r 

# Should be executed in a separate session, otherwise it will not work
# Specify settings for the Policy

ore.exec("BEGIN ctx_ddl.drop_policy('wiki_txtpol'); EXCEPTION WHEN OTHERS THEN NULL; END;")
ore.exec("BEGIN ctx_ddl.drop_preference( 'wiki_lexer'); EXCEPTION WHEN OTHERS THEN NULL; END;")
ore.exec("BEGIN ctx_ddl.create_preference('wiki_lexer', 'BASIC_LEXER'); END;")
ore.exec("BEGIN ctx_ddl.set_attribute('wiki_lexer', 'INDEX_STEMS', 'ENGLISH'); END;")
ore.exec("BEGIN ctx_ddl.create_policy(policy_name => 'wiki_txtpol', lexer => 'wiki_lexer'); END;")

%md ### The pre-built Wikipedia model must be loaded to the Oracle Autonomous Database. It is a relatively large model object at 800 MB. #### Follow the setup in template notebook *OML Import ESA Wiki Model* #### Relevant Oracle blogs: 1. New Wikipedia-Based Cognitive Model Available for Text Processing 2. Text Analytics using a pre-built Wikipedia-based Topic Model 3. Explicit Semantic Analysis (ESA) for Text Analytics We will also need to create a model proxy object for the Wiki model into OML4R - Use the included function ore.createESA.wiki_model() to create our proxy object - This function retrieves information about the Wikipedia model and uses that information to create our ESA model using the ore.odmESA function

msg.data:
The pre-built Wikipedia model must be loaded to the Oracle Autonomous Database. It is a relatively large model object at 800 MB.

Follow the setup in template notebook OML Import ESA Wiki Model

Relevant Oracle blogs:

  1. New Wikipedia-Based Cognitive Model Available for Text Processing
  2. Text Analytics using a pre-built Wikipedia-based Topic Model
  3. Explicit Semantic Analysis (ESA) for Text Analytics

We will also need to create a model proxy object for the Wiki model into OML4R

  • Use the included function ore.createESA.wiki_model() to create our proxy object
  • This function retrieves information about the Wikipedia model and uses that information to create our ESA model using the ore.odmESA function

paragraphs.title: Import libraries and set options
paragraphs.text:
%r

library(ORE)
options(ore.warn.order=FALSE)

paragraphs.title: # Check to see if the pre-loaded model is available
paragraphs.text:
%sql

-- We should expect one row with the model WIKI_MODEL
select MODEL_NAME, MINING_FUNCTION, ALGORITHM, ALGORITHM_TYPE, CREATION_DATE from USER_MINING_MODELS where MODEL_NAME='WIKI_MODEL'

table.tableOptionSpecHash: [{"name":"useFilter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable filter for columns"},{"name":"showPagination","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable pagination for better navigation"},{"name":"showAggregationFooter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable a footer for displaying aggregated values"}]

msg.data:
MODEL_NAME	MINING_FUNCTION	ALGORITHM	ALGORITHM_TYPE	CREATION_DATE
WIKI_MODEL	FEATURE_EXTRACTION	EXPLICIT_SEMANTIC_ANALYS	NATIVE	2022-07-29 16:32:50

paragraphs.title: Create function for getting proxy model object for the pre-loaded Wikipedia Model
paragraphs.text:
%r
 
ore.createESA.wiki_model <- function () {
  model.name <- "WIKI_MODEL"
  attr(model.name, "owner") <- OREbase:::.ore.schema()
  formula <- "~ TEXT"
  formula <- as.formula(formula, env = parent.frame())
  env.lst <- list()
  model.settings   <- OREdm:::.ore.getModelSettings(model.name,"esas_")
  model.attributes <- OREdm:::.ore.getModelAttributes(model.name)
  query <- paste(
    "SELECT ",
    "FEATURE_ID, ",
    "nvl2(attribute_subname, ", "attribute_name","||","'.'", "||",
    "attribute_subname,  attribute_name) attribute_name,",
    "COEFFICIENT ",
    "FROM ", "DM$VAWIKI_MODEL",
    " where ROWNUM <= 10 order by 1,2,3",
    sep="");
  features.all <- OREdm:::.ore.frame4query(query, extRef = env.lst)
  esa.mod <- OREdm:::.create.ore.odmESA(model.name,
                                        model.settings,
                                        model.attributes,
                                        formula,
                                        env.lst,
                                        match.call(),
                                        features=features.all)
}

paragraphs.title: Call the function to obtain proxy object
paragraphs.text:
%r 

esa_wiki_mod <- ore.createESA.wiki_model()

paragraphs.title: Check the first 100 rows of the 21.7 mi rows of features
paragraphs.text:
%r
 
z.show(head(features(esa_wiki_mod), 100))

paragraphs.title: Basic settings of the ESA model and the 21.7 mi rows of features
paragraphs.text:
%r

summary(esa_wiki_mod)

ore.createESA.wiki_model()

Settings: 
                                               value
min.items                                         25
topn.features                                   1000
value.threshold                            .00000001
odms.details                             odms.enable
odms.missing.value.treatment odms.missing.value.auto
odms.sampling                  odms.sampling.disable
odms.text.max.features                        200000
odms.text.min.documents                            5
odms.text.policy.name                    wiki_txtpol
prep.auto                                         ON

%md
# Examples using the Wiki ESA model

msg.data: Examples using the Wiki ESA model

paragraphs.title: Basic example of ESA features for the word 'Bank' using the Wikipedia Model
paragraphs.text:
%r

TEMP_DF <- ore.push(data.frame(TEXT = c("Bank")))

z.show(predict(esa_wiki_mod, TEMP_DF, type = c("class", "raw"))[-c(3)])

paragraphs.title: ESA features for a long text about the Oracle Machine Learning AutoML UI using the Wikipedia Model
paragraphs.text:
%r

TEMP_DF <- ore.push(data.frame(ID = 1, TEXT = c("Oracle Machine Learning AutoML User Interface makes it easy for citizen data scientists and expert data scientists to build and deploy machine learning models. OML AutoML UI, a new component of Oracle Machine Learning on Oracle Autonomous Database, provides a no-code browser-based interface that automates the machine learning modeling process and simplifies deployment to just a few clicks. While data scientists may prefer to write code, perhaps using the OML4Py AutoML feature, OML AutoML UI makes machine learning possible for a much broader set of users, who may “know enough ML to be dangerous” but are not familiar with specific algorithm details and the modeling process to refine usable models. At the same time, OML AutoML UI delivers significant productivity improvements for data scientists as a modeling accelerator.")))

z.show(predict(esa_wiki_mod, TEMP_DF, type = c("class", "raw"))[-c(3)])

paragraphs.text:
%md
# Comparing Strings for Similarity of Text using the Wikipedia Model

msg.data: Comparing Strings for Similarity of Text using the Wikipedia Model

paragraphs.title: Comparison of "fish" vs "salmon" using the Wikipedia model
paragraphs.text:
%r

TEMP_DF <- ore.push(data.frame(TEXT = c("fish", "salmon")))

z.show(feature_compare(esa_wiki_mod, TEMP_DF, compare.cols = "TEXT"))

paragraphs.title: Comparison of "fish" vs "hawk" using the Wikipedia Model
paragraphs.text:
%r

TEMP_DF <- ore.push(data.frame(TEXT = c("fish", "hawk")))

z.show(feature_compare(esa_wiki_mod, TEMP_DF, compare.cols = "TEXT"))

paragraphs.title: Text about OML4R and SailGP using the Wikipedia Model
paragraphs.text:
%r

TEMP_DF <- ore.push(data.frame(TEXT = c("OML4R has data types that map R data types to SQL data types. In an R session, when you create database objects from R objects or you create R objects from database data, OML4R translates R data types to SQL data types and the reverse where possible. OML4R creates objects that are instances of OML4R classes. OML4R overloads many standard R functions so that they use OML4R classes and data types. R language constructs and syntax are supported for objects that are mapped to Oracle Database objects.", "In the SailGP league, thousands of sensors are attached to the catamarans and their crew members, generating millions of data points that are shared with broadcast partners, fans, race officials, and importantly, across the fleet. Each team has full access to one another’s data for post-race analysis, with the goal that sailing performance on the water, not technology, should determine the winner. ")))

z.show(feature_compare(esa_wiki_mod, TEMP_DF, compare.cols = "TEXT"))

paragraphs.title: Text about OML4R and OML4Py using the Wikipedia Model
paragraphs.text:
%r 

TEMP_DF <- ore.push(data.frame(TEXT = c("OML4R has data types that map R data types to SQL data types. In an R session, when you create database objects from R objects or you create R objects from database data, OML4R translates R data types to SQL data types and the reverse where possible. OML4R creates objects that are instances of OML4R classes. OML4R overloads many standard R functions so that they use OML4R classes and data types. R language constructs and syntax are supported for objects that are mapped to Oracle Database objects.", "Oracle Machine Learning for Python (OML4Py) is a component of the Oracle Database Enterprise Edition that makes open source Python ready for the enterprise and big data. OML4Py integrates Python with the Oracle Database and provides a comprehensive, database-centric environment for end-to-end analytical processing. OML4Py provides the users the capability to execute Python functions on database-resident data for data exploration and preparation, whilst seamlessly leveraging the Oracle Database as a high-performance computing (HPC) environment. Furthermore, Python users can natively invoke powerful in-database machine learning algorithms directly in Python.")))

z.show(feature_compare(esa_wiki_mod, TEMP_DF, compare.cols = "TEXT"))
